questions.prompt: A function φ: G → H between groups is a homomorphism if:
options: φ(ab) = φ(a)φ(b) for all a, b ∈ G
φ(a) = a for all a ∈ G
φ maps the identity to the identity
questions.explanation: A homomorphism preserves the group operation: φ(ab) = φ(a)φ(b). This automatically implies φ(e_G) = e_H and φ(a⁻¹) = φ(a)⁻¹.

questions.prompt: If φ: G → H is a group homomorphism, then φ(e_G) equals:
questions.explanation: Every homomorphism maps the identity of G to the identity of H. This follows from φ(e_G) = φ(e_G · e_G) = φ(e_G)φ(e_G).

questions.prompt: An isomorphism is a homomorphism that is:
questions.explanation: An isomorphism is a bijective homomorphism. Two groups are isomorphic if there exists an isomorphism between them.

questions.prompt: Which of the following is a homomorphism from (Z, +) to (Z, +)?
questions.explanation: φ(n) = 2n is a homomorphism since φ(m+n) = 2(m+n) = 2m + 2n = φ(m) + φ(n). The others fail the homomorphism property.

questions.prompt: If φ: G → H is a homomorphism and a has order n in G, then φ(a) in H has order:
questions.explanation: If |a| = n, then φ(a)ⁿ = φ(aⁿ) = φ(e) = e, so |φ(a)| divides n. The order can be less than n (e.g., if a is in the kernel).

title: Homomorphisms and Isomorphisms - Kernels and Isomorphism Theorems

questions.prompt: The kernel of a homomorphism φ: G → H is:
questions.explanation: The kernel is ker(φ) = {g ∈ G : φ(g) = e_H}. It is always a normal subgroup of G.

questions.prompt: A homomorphism φ: G → H is injective if and only if:
questions.explanation: φ is injective (one-to-one) if and only if its kernel is trivial: ker(φ) = {e_G}.

questions.prompt: The First Isomorphism Theorem states that if φ: G → H is a homomorphism, then:
questions.explanation: The First Isomorphism Theorem: If φ: G → H is a homomorphism, then G/ker(φ) ≅ im(φ).

questions.prompt: Consider the homomorphism φ: Z → Z₆ defined by φ(n) = n mod 6. What is ker(φ)?
questions.explanation: ker(φ) = {n ∈ Z : n ≡ 0 (mod 6)} = 6Z, the set of all multiples of 6.

questions.prompt: The image (range) of a homomorphism φ: G → H is:
questions.explanation: The image im(φ) = {φ(g) : g ∈ G} is always a subgroup of H, though not necessarily all of H.

questions.prompt: A group action of G on a set X is a function G × X → X such that:
options: e · x = x and (gh) · x = g · (h · x) for all g, h ∈ G and x ∈ X
g · x = x for all g and x
g · x ≠ x for all g ≠ e
questions.explanation: A group action satisfies: (1) the identity acts trivially: e·x = x, and (2) the action respects composition: (gh)·x = g·(h·x).

questions.prompt: The orbit of an element x ∈ X under a group action is:
questions.explanation: The orbit of x is Orb(x) = {g·x : g ∈ G}, the set of all elements that x can be moved to by the group action.

questions.prompt: The stabilizer of an element x ∈ X is:
questions.explanation: The stabilizer of x is Stab(x) = {g ∈ G : g·x = x}, the subgroup of elements that fix x.
The Orbit-Stabilizer Theorem: For a finite group G acting on X, |G| = |Orb(x)| · |Stab(x)| for any x ∈ X. Equivalently, |Orb(x)| = [G : Stab(x)].

questions.prompt: An automorphism of a group G is:
options: Any homomorphism from G to G
An isomorphism from G to itself
questions.explanation: An automorphism is an isomorphism φ: G → G. The set of all automorphisms forms a group Aut(G) under composition.
